title: Trainer Nick Gonzalez takes a shot at Breeders' Cup Juvenile with Riker
text:

He has won a Queen's Plate in the past and currently trains an impressive, undefeated two-year-old colt, so why wouldn't trainer Nick Gonzalez dream big? 
The colt in question, two-year-old thoroughbred Riker, heads a sizeable Canadian contingent preparing for the season-ending Breeders' Cup championship next week in Lexington, Ky. 
And based on his colt's undefeated record -- and especially his effort in his most recent win -- Gonzalez is ready to take his shot. 
"We're dreaming the dream," said Gonzalez of Riker, whose credentials were enhanced significantly when he captured the Grey Stakes at Woodbine earlier this month to push his undefeated career record to four consecutive wins. "The thought of being in a race like the Breeders' Cup always makes you feel great." 
It certainly will be a step up in class for Riker, who will face the best-bred young prospects in the world, many of them trained by the most accomplished trainers in the sport. But it's difficult to deny him a spot in the starting gate. 
Riker's decisive win in the Grey earned him a spot in the $2-million Breeders' Cup Juvenile, one of the most anticipated dashes on the Cup card as it provides an early look at next year's Triple Crown contenders. Most encouraging for Gonzalez is that the colt seems to improve with each start, something he will have to do again at Keeneland Race Course when he faces the top young colts in the game. 
"He keeps getting better every time he races," said Gonzalez, who captured the 2010 Queen's Plate with Big Red Mike. "It's been wonderful to see that progression. I was really impressed by how he galloped out after the Grey. 
"We're obviously thrilled with how he's raced. I have a very good feeling about this horse." 
Based on the pre-entries announced by Breeders' Cup officials, Riker is just one of many Canadian-connected horses headed to Kentucky for racing's two-day, season-ending championship, including a shed row full from Canada's perennial trainer of the year, Mark Casse.
